Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of the Mechanical Environment of Bone Marrow During Skeletal Loading

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to understand how the pressure and motion of bone marrow within the trabecular - or spongy - bone in the hip are affected by forces during walking. The bone marrow in the hip is one of the main sites where hematopoietic (blood forming) and mesenchymal (skeletal tissue forming) stem cells are found in adults, although their numbers decline with age. Studies have demonstrated that mesenchymal stem cells, while few in number, are highly sensitive to mechanical stimulation, but the types and magnitudes of stimuli they experience in the body are largely unknown. An experimental study will be conducted to measure the pressure at different locations within the hip during simulated walking. Data from the experiments will be incorporated into computational models to estimate the pressure throughout the bone. A second set of models will employ these calculated pressures to determine the motion of the marrow at the microscopic scale, and the distribution of mechanical stimuli in the marrow.

If successful, these studies will provide insight into the mechanical environment of bone marrow and the range of stresses that are imparted to adult stem cells on a daily basis. These results will improve interpretation and design of cell culture experiments and tissue engineering constructs by providing baseline stimulus levels. They may also provide insight into changes in the bone marrow, such as the decline in the mesenchymal stem cell population with age. Finally, the computational models can be used to predict the behavior in response to abnormal loading or disease conditions. To extend the impact of this project to the wider community, a high-school teacher will participate in the research, and the project team will help them incorporate the methods and findings into courses and projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bone marrow is a complex and important tissue in the human skeleton. Like other tissues, it is affected by disease and aging. However, the affects of aging, such as increased fat content can be modulated by skeletal loading such as vibration or pressure. While it is known that the cells in the marrow are sensitive to mechanical stimulation, the mechanical environment of marrow, has not been well characterized.

Femurs (thigh bones) of pigs were obtained from a local slaughter house, and used throughout the study. Pig bones were used, because they can be easily obtained near the time of death without refrigeration or preservation. This is essential, as the investigators showed in a preliminary study that refrigeration or freezing affects the mechanical behavior of the bone marrow.

Mechanical testing of the femurs was conducted to simulate normal walking. The bones were tested in a water tank that maintained the bones at body temperature. Sensor attached to the bones during tested recorded the pressure within the bone marrow as well as the deformation on the surface. 

Three dimensional images of the bones were captured by computed tomography and used to create computational models. The models demonstrated that compression of the bone forced the marrow to flow through small pores within the bone. The resulting motion caused mechanical stress on the cells that would be sufficient to cause a biological response.

Taken together, the results suggest that bone marrow is stimulated by the compression of the bones during normal daily activities. This stimulation could affect normal physiology and health, as the bone marrow cells are involved in the maintenance of bone and the production of blood and immune cells.

Broader Impacts

This project has had multiple impacts. The project had improved international collaboration, as two graduate students working directly on this project had the opportunity to study and perform research in Galway, Ireland. These visits were supported by Science Foundation Ireland, Whitaker International, and the Fulbright Scholars program. In addition two graduate students and one post-doctoral researcher from Galway spent periods working in our laboratory.

Two local high school students worked on aspects of this project, as did a local high school science teacher. One of the students, Ms. Christine Mai,  received an award for best cancer related project at the Northern Indiana Regional Science Fair. As a result of these projects, we have developed an ongoing relationship to engage talented students in real laboratory research.

The research has been broadly disseminated, with presentations at national and international meetings, and with nine publications in the peer reviewed literature, with several publications to be submitted in the next year.
